column4: Does anyone know if Ubuntu 'hibernate' (suspend-to-disk) will allow me to boot another partition after hibernating and then still resume?
if the OS on the other partition does not touch any of the partitions the hibernated one has open... sure
are you sure that Ubuntu S2D doesn't write anything int he boot sector or partition tables that may conflict with another os?

yes... it just writes the contents of memory out to swap... so if you want to resume windows... that's fine, as long as you didn't have any of your windows partitions mounted when you hibernate ubuntu
I share a single swap partition with different Linuxes(spel?)...
then don't try to boot those linuxes when you hibernate
what if the swapspace is less than my RAM?

it does not matter... when you hibernate, the ram is written to the swap partition... most likely another linux install you try to boot will refuse to touch the swap partition because the signature will be changed... unless that installation is also configured to resume
it also sets a switch in the GRUB bootloader to pass an argument to vmlinuz (or in an init script perhaps?) does it not?
what's that?  I set up my grun to pass the resume= parameter to point the system to my swap partition
it would break the resume, yes
can I tell Ubuntu to write the file somewhere else and just set it -ro?
I think you can use a swap file instead of a swap partition... never tried it though
but could it cause arbitrary system calls to exec in a way that would actually hurt Ubuntu in a persistent sense?
no... not in a persistent sense... it will just bust the resume
something like WinBlows hiberfil.sys would be _suite_
does Ubuntu run a CRC (or any other integrity check) on the hiberfile?
yes... if it is clobbered by the other install, the resume will simply fail and ubuntu will boot up normally
